designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific series is one of the flagship publications of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and is identified as an ADB corporate priority technical 
assistance (TA) project for 2012. Each annual Key Indicators volume includes a special chapter 
that provides in-depth and data-intensive policy analysis of prevailing critical policy issues, and 
a  comprehensive  compendium  and  analysis  of  trends  in  economic,  social,  financial,  and 
Millennium Development Goal indicators for 48 ADB regional members. These statistics are 
widely used by the development community, policy makers, civil society, the private sector, and 
academia.  
 
2.  In order for the Key Indicators series to effectively  promote ADB’s reputation as a 
credible source of knowledge about the region, and serve as an effective instrument for better 
informed policies and projects, it is essential that rigorous research on the topic selected for the 
special chapter be undertaken, along with intensive data validation, analysis and compilation; 
extensive collaboration with statistical partners; and wider and effective dissemination of the 
resulting publication. This TA will ensure that these activities are carried out effectively. The 
TA’s design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Compared to other regions, the economy of Asia and the Pacific has grown at a record 
pace for the period 1992–2008 and still continues to grow until 2012. Many of ADB’s developing 
member countries (DMCs) are expected to achieve the Millennium Development Goals by 2015. 
However,  despite  the  region’s  remarkable  success  in  lifting  many  people  out  of  poverty, 
development challenges such as rising inequality are pervasive, and new issues continue to 
emerge. As a result, there is continuing demand for sound policy research that is grounded in 
data-intensive analysis, which has proven to be a key factor in effectively addressing these 
challenges. 
 
4.  In  2012  the  Key  Indicators  special  chapter  will  tackle  two  growing  concerns—
environmental sustainability and rapid urbanization. Through rigorous econometric methods that 
use a variety of survey data and aggregate country-level data, as well as in-depth country-level 
studies, the research examines developments in urban planning, low-carbon transport, green 
industry,  green  infrastructure  and  the  role  of  technology,  and  other  areas,  and  draws 
appropriate policy recommendations. Other topics that will be investigated are the impact of 
urbanization on the environment, society, and the economy; the drivers of urbanization; urban 
planning issues; and associated policy implications.  
 
5.  Data-intensive policy analysis such as has been outlined for this year’s special chapter 
on ―Green Urbanization‖ requires time and resources. Under the current business process, 
there is limited time in the publication’s annual production schedule to undertake rigorous data 
analysis and consolidate research results for a comprehensive policy discussion. As a result, it 
is prudent that potential topics for the special chapters of future Key Indicators volumes be 
promptly identified and that the topic for the 2013 issue be determined much earlier than the 
onset of the next production schedule, thereby allowing more in-depth policy research to be 
undertaken.

6.  The  Key  Indicators  series  also  contributes  to  the  region’s  goal  of  achieving  better 
development outcomes by compiling and disseminating timely and reliable indicators to ADB 
regional members. Effective monitoring of policies and identification of emerging concerns also 
requires data that are updated and consistent across economies. More than 100 government 
agencies in 48 regional ADB members provide the Key Indicators with their official statistics. 
These  data  are  validated  and  uploaded  to  ADB’s  Statistical  Database  System  (SDBS),2 
enabling their use for the Key Indicators statistical tables as well as online dissemination, 
whereby other users can download them for other purposes. The business process for data 
validation and compilation, generation of statistical tables, and dissemination of statistics for the 
Key Indicators volumes must be further automated to improve data quality and provide better 
and  more  timely  access  to  the  data  and  indicators  in  the  publication.  Also,  while  many 
development  organizations  have  begun  providing  the  statistics  and  analytical  reports  they 
compile through handheld devices, the main dissemination platforms for the Key Indicators 
remains personal computers and the Internet.  
 
7.  An important result of the data validation and analysis process for Key Indicators shows 
that many DMCs—especially those with weak statistical systems—have not yet complied with 
internationally accepted concepts and data standards, including that of timeliness. While ADB 
continues to provide TA to DMCs to build the capacity of their national statistical systems and 
thereby improve data quality and coverage, major constraints remain, including (i) a lack of 
government support; (ii) a lack of information about new data initiatives and resources that could 
be tapped to improve data standards; and (iii) inadequate skills for adapting data standards, 
which persist and can hinder the timeliness and data consistency of official statistics.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA aims to improve the coverage and use of ADB’s annual Key Indicators series for 
more effective evidence-based policy making and analysis. The expected outcome of the TA is 
the effective dissemination of the 2012 Key Indicators. 
 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will support the following key activities: (i) publication of the 2012 Key Indicators 
including  data-intensive  research  on  ―Green  Urbanization‖. (ii)  enhancement  of the quality, 
coverage, consistency and timeliness of official data and indicators; and (iii) improvement of the 
business processes for data validation, analysis, compilation, production, dissemination of the 
publication, and thorough analysis of important policy issues with identification of emerging 
critical issues for future special chapters of the Key Indicators series;  
 
10.  Research on the rapid urbanization taking place in Asia and its relationship to other 
emerging local and global challenges will be undertaken. The research will extrapolate ways in 
which policies can help effectively manage urbanization, which can lead to more rapid and 
effective poverty reduction and inclusive growth in Asia and the Pacific.  Background research 
papers will be commissioned to explore topics related to urbanization, such as the impact of

urbanization on the environment, society, and economy; the drivers of urbanization; urban 
planning issues; and policy implications. Studies on urban planning, low-carbon transport, green 
industry, green infrastructure and the role of technology, and other issues will be consolidated 
and  analyzed  further  to  draw  appropriate  policy  recommendations  from  an  economic 
perspective.  
 
11.  The conduct of Key Indicators workshops and seminars is crucial to the development of 
the special chapter, and will firm up initial findings based on the background research papers, 
as well as identify and discuss the constraints and general direction of the special chapter. 
Distinguished  experts  will  be  invited  to  the  workshops.  The  outputs  of  the  Key  Indicators 
workshops will provide credible statistics and useful inputs on the topic of the special chapter. 
Research,  consultations,  and  discussions  through  participation  of  staff  in  regional  and 
international conferences and seminars will also be undertaken to identify emerging concerns 
that can be potential topics for future Key Indicators publications. In preparation for the 2012 
Key Indicators publication, a workshop will be held to which prominent researchers and key 
government representatives will be invited.  
 
12.  Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2012 will also feature the second edition of the 
Framework of Inclusive Growth Indicators (FIGI) supplement,3 which identifies 35 indicators that 
include  the  policy  ingredients  of  inclusive  growth—economic  growth  and  employment 
opportunities, social inclusion, social protection, as well as good governance and institutions. 
With the well-received first edition of FIGI and with the current trend of economic research that 
goes  beyond  gross  domestic  product  to  measure  growth  and  wellbeing,  continuing  the 
development and dissemination of FIGI will support ADB’s focus on better policies to achieve 
inclusive growth through evidence-based policy making. 
 
13.   To further support and complement the earlier work done on inclusive growth, methods 
will be developed to measure inclusive growth, which will take into account growth in income 
and non-income development outcomes such as health and education. Distribution of these 
outcomes across different subpopulations will be incorporated into the methods as well. These 
methods will then be used to empirically evaluate the extent to which growth in Asia has been 
inclusive,  both  across  different  dimensions  and  subpopulations,  and  thereby  aid  in  the 
identification of development gaps and the formulation of relevant policies.  
 
14.  Statistical consultation workshops on key data issues encountered in the preparation of 
the  Key  Indicators  will  be  held  with  representatives  of  statistical  partners.  Updates  on 
international data compilation standards and current trends in data compilation methods will be 
presented in the workshops. These consultations and discussions will be continued through a 
community of practice website that the TA will initiate and support, to allow an exchange of 
ideas and compilation methods among statistical partners in the Asia and the Pacific. Seminars, 
workshops and conferences to improve data compilation methods that are organized by other 
development organizations can also be supported, if requested. Higher quality official statistics 
that are produced by statistical partners will contribute to better policy making and development 
outcomes in the long term.  
 
15.   The  business  processes  pertaining  to  the  production  of  the  Key  Indicators  will  be 
automated to improve the timeliness of data dissemination and the production schedule of the 
publication. User-friendly interfaces will be incorporated in the automated system to enhance

the efficiency of data validation and report generation processes. Analytical applications such as 
visualization through graphs, maps and other graphical tools and generation of statistical tables 
will be undertaken for both handheld devices and personal computers to expand the Key 
Indicators user base.  
 
16.  Writers’ workshops will also be organized to improve the drafting of the analysis of key 
trends that are part of the statistical tables. Data attributes—especially the concepts, definitions 
and deviations from standards that pertain to each data series—will be compiled and updated to 
provide a better gauge of reliability to users. To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency in 
approach across the different parts of the  Key Indicators, high-quality editing services are 
required.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency. The TA will be implemented by the Development 
Indicators and Policy Research Division (ERDI) for 19 months, beginning 1 June  2012 until its 
targeted completion on 31 December 2013.  
 
19.  ERDI will closely collaborate with regional departments, including resident missions and 
other international organizations that have common interests in gathering data from its statistical 
partners in ADB’s regional members and in organizing the data consultation workshops in 
selected subregional centers. ERDI will continue to work with the Office of Information Systems 
and Technology in completing the automation of business processes for SDBS and the Key 
Indicators, including the development of an application for handheld devices. ERDI will also 
coordinate with other development organizations that are conducting statistics capacity-building 
activities to improve the quality and coverage of official statistics in the region to optimize the 
limited resources available for this purpose. Dissemination activities will be coordinated with the 
Department of External Relations. 
 
20.  An estimated 14 person-months of international individual consultant services and 77 
person-months of national individual consultant services will be required to assist ERDI staff in 
undertaking all the activities discussed above. The Institute for International Economic Policy 
(IIEP) at the George Washington University, is the most appropriate institution to undertake 
these services. IIEP is the most prominent institution in the field of multidimensional poverty 
analysis as it has the IIEP Ultra-Poverty Initiative which exclusively focuses on poverty research 
and inclusive growth. Further, this Initiative is headed by Professor J. Foster, who developed the 
poverty measure which has been used in the poverty estimates which ADB reports as well as 
globally,  including  by  the  UN,  other  MDBs  and  the  research  community.  Its  widely  cited 
research places it as the leading center for scholarship on global poverty, and it has shown a 
keen interest in working in this region. Thus, IIEP is best suited to be engaged for $100,000 
through single-source selection to develop methods to measure inclusive growth and conduct 
empirical and policy-relevant studies.  The terms of reference for the individual consultants and 
IIEP  are  in  Appendix  3.  IIEP  will  provide  an  estimated  6  person-months  of  international 
consultant services and 3 person-months of national consultant services.

5 
21.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). All the procurement to be financed under the TA will be carried out in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2012, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consultants for the Statistical Tables and Special Chapter of Key Indicators for 
Asia and the Pacific 2012 and Related Research 
 
1.   Economist  (international,  four  positions,  2  person-months  each,  intermittent).  The 
economists  should  hold  PhD  degrees  in  economics  and  have  strong  backgrounds  in 
development economics, urban economics and/or regional economics. They must each have a 
good publication record on urbanization or related issues, preferably related to Asian economies. 
Quantitative and econometric skills are necessary. In particular, the economists will: 
(i)  conduct research and prepare background papers for the special chapter on 
issues related to economic development, urbanization, inclusive growth, 
vulnerability, poverty, inequality, and other emerging topics; 
(ii)  prepare relevant literature reviews, collect and compile data, and conduct 
quantitative modeling using the latest techniques; 
(iii)  explore specific evidence-based policies and interventions; and 
(iv)  prepare and/or revise well-written paper(s) for publications. 
 
2.  Economics editor (international, 1.5 person-months, intermittent). The economics editor 
should have (i) at least a master’s degree, and preferably a PhD in economics; (ii) knowledge of 
development and urbanization issues in developing Asia; (iii) proven capacity to synthesize 
complex issues and identify key policy messages for policy makers and other key stakeholders; 
and  (iv)  a  good  publication  record.  The  economics  editor  will  be  responsible  for  providing 
technical guidance and advice, economics editing of the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 
2012 special chapter, and assisting in preparing the Key Indicators highlights for 2012, including 
the tables and charts included in the publication, and the presentation materials for the launch of 
the 2012 publication.  
 
3.  In particular, the economics editor for the special chapter will carry out and highlight the 
following:  
(i)   provide technical advice and guidance, and  
(a) critically examine the contents of the various sections of the special chapter 
for consistency with economic theory and empirical evidence;  
(b)  identify gaps,  weaknesses  and  concerns,  and  make recommendations for 
revisions of the chapter sections;  
(c)  discuss suggested changes and revisions with Development Indicators and 
Policy Research Division (ERDI) staff; and  
(d)  write the highlights of the special chapter in conjunction with ERDI staff; and  
(ii)   conduct economics editing, and specifically  
(a) edit and revise the special chapter as agreed;  
(b) review the structure, content, and format of the draft special chapter to ensure 
it conforms to the prescribed requirements for Key Indicators for Asia and the 
Pacific 2012; and  
(c) confirm the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in 
the special chapter. 
 
4.  Research  analysts  (national,  two  positions,  8  person-months  each).  The  research 
analysts  must  have  previous  work  experience  with  database  management  (especially  on 
processing and encoding of large-scale household survey data). They should also have a strong 
background in statistical and econometric analysis and should possess at least a bachelor’s 
degree  (and  preferably  a  master’s  degree)  in  economics,  statistics  or  a  related  field.  The

candidates  should  be  adept  in  the  technical  and  analytical  skills  required  for  the  technical 
assistance (TA) project and proficient in using STATA or other statistical software for data 
analysis. The candidates should have a strong background working with official (government-
produced) statistics. In particular, the consultants will:  
(i)   gather macro- and micro-data as needed for the research or technical papers,  
(ii)   perform econometric and statistical analysis on the data,  
(iii)   prepare technical documentation,  
(iv)   assist in preparing draft papers and reports, and  
(v)   perform other research-related tasks as needed. 
 
B.  Consultants for the Statistical Tables  
 
5.  Economics  and  statistics  specialists  (national,  seven  positions,  6  person-months 
each).  The  consultants  should  have  a  background  in  economics/statistics  and  experience 
working  with  official  (government-produced)  statistics.  They  should  also  have  advanced 
knowledge of MS Excel and automated business processes. They must exercise due diligence in 
undertaking processes concerning data compilation and validation. Moreover, they should have 
good writing skills. In particular, the consultants will assist ERDI staff in performing the following 
tasks: 
(i)  compile  and  validate  statistics  from  assigned  regional  members  and  other 
sources; 
(ii)  generate, review and finalize assigned statistical tables under the guidance of 
ERDI international staff and the Key Indicators coordinator using applications of 
the Statistical Database System (SDBS); 
(iii)  study the assigned theme, and together with their ERDI staff counterpart, analyze 
the available data and other information; 
(iv)  review and update the statistical definitions and concepts that are used in the 
preparation of the Key Indicators; 
(v)  write a report on the analysis of the assigned theme;  
(vi)  prepare materials for discussions in the subregional data consultation workshops; 
(vii)  participate in the writing workshop and assist in the integration of the analytical 
report in the Key Indicators publication; and 
(viii)  perform other related technical and administrative tasks as may be assigned by 
the Key Indicators coordinator. 
 
6.  Information technology expert/statistician (national, 3 person-months, intermittent). 
The information technology (IT) expert/statistician must have extensive knowledge in statistical 
data systems and IT concerning applications for handheld devices such as the iPad,  other 
tablets and/or Android phones. The consultant will be responsible for designing and developing 
an application that publishes or disseminates the Key Indicators, including all statistical tables, 
through such handheld devices. In particular, the consultant will: 
(i)  design a user-friendly and interactive application for handheld devices that will 
disseminate the Key Indicators, including all statistical tables and figures; 
(ii)  work with the ADB units concerned in ascertaining that design requirements are 
satisfied; and 
(iii)  in collaboration with ADB units concerned, implement the approved design until 
the final production version.  
 
7.  Statistician  (international,  2  person-months,  intermittent).  The  statistician  must  have 
good familiarity with official statistics produced in Asia and the Pacific; must be knowledgeable in 
current international data standards, such as those on national accounts, balance of payments,

C.  Consultants for the Key Indicators Special Supplement (Framework of Inclusive 
Growth Indicators) 
 
10.  Inclusive growth expert (international, 1.0 person-month). The consultant should have a 
strong background using socioeconomic indicators and national household survey data for policy 
analysis and must be an excellent writer. The expert should preferably have experience with 
international organizations and considerable experience conducting research on development 
policy, and especially economic growth, poverty, and inclusive growth, with a particular focus on 
social sector issues in developing countries in Asia. The consultant will: 
(i)  become familiar with the Framework of Inclusive Growth Indicators (FIGI) and 
recommend modifications to the indicators, if warranted, including justifications; 
(ii)  draft an analytical  writeup—based on the data compiled for the FIGI indicators 
and other relevant materials, or on a selected (to be determined) theme or topic of 
the FIGI—from the perspective of inclusive growth in developing Asia;  
(iii)  develop policy prescriptions needed for inclusive growth for the selected theme;  
(iv)  discuss on a regular basis with the project officer any issues encountered in the 
drafting of the paper; present the draft paper in the Economics and Research 
Department seminar series, and/or other workshops as needed, for the purpose of 
soliciting further comments for improvements and fine-tuning of the methodology 
and overall paper quality;  
(v)  finalize the draft report based on solicited comments; and  
(vi)  perform other related tasks as discussed with the project officer. 
 
11.  Economics and statistics research assistant (national, two positions for 7 person-
months  each).    The  consultants  should  have  a  background  in  economics/statistics  and 
experience working with socioeconomic statistics, preferably in the area of official statistics. They 
should possess excellent skills using MS Excel and, preferably a working knowledge of STATA 
or  other  similar  statistical  processing  software.  They  should  be  familiar  with  international 
databases, particularly those related to inclusive growth, be able to document procedures and 
other important information, and possess excellent organizing skills. The consultants will: 
(i)  update  the  data  and  identified  data  sources,  metadata  (definitions,  sources, 
availability, and other relevant information) for all the indicators included in FIGI;  
(ii)  organize the data files of the indicators in a time-series database form to facilitate 
data retrieval, as well as understanding and management of data;  
(iii)  conduct additional research in relation to the selected indicators included in FIGI 
and explore new/alternative indicators, if needed;  
(iv)  identify data sources for more disaggregated data for sub-national populations for 
selected indicators; 
(v)  prepare data tables, ensure the accuracy of data in the tables, and assist in 
writing statistical commentaries and analysis for the 2012 edition of FIGI; and 
(vi)  perform other tasks as needed. 
 
12.  Copy  editor  (national,  1  person-month).  The  copy  editor  will  be  responsible  for 
copyediting the Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2012 special supplement, including the 
publication’s tables and charts, following the ADB Handbook of Style and Usage (footnote 1). 
The editing will include a number of editing rounds of the typeset version until the desired quality 
is achieved. The copy editor will also make suggestions regarding the layout. In particular, the 
copy editor will: 
(i)  reorganize the text so that the subject matter is easy to understand and is logically 
presented;

(ii)  eliminate wordiness and repetition, and reduce ambiguity; 
(iii)  query discrepancies, possible typographical errors, and non-English terms; 
(iv)  edit tables and figures, and recast if required; 
(v)  find  obvious  errors  and  point  out  questionable  proper  names,  bibliographic 
references, and similar mistakes (but excluding fact checking); 
(vi)  ensure that subheadings are consistent and logical; 
(vii)  check references to tables, figures, appendixes, and parts of the text; 
(viii)  edit notes to ensure that the text references are correct; 
(ix)  edit reference lists; 
(x)  check final changes; 
(xi)  work closely with the project officer in charge of FIGI; and 
(xii)  check and sign off on the layout.  
 
13.  Consulting  firm:  measurement  of  inclusive  growth  and  poverty  in  Asia.    The 
Institute for International Economic Policy (IIEP) of the George Washington University will be 
recruited to develop methods for measuring inclusive growth. These methods will take into 
account  growth  in  income  and  non-income  development  outcomes  such  as  health  and 
education. It will empirically evaluate the extent to which growth in Asia has been inclusive 
across  different  dimensions  and  subpopulations  and  thereby  aid  in  the  identification  of 
development gaps and the formulation of relevant policies. Distribution of these outcomes across 
different  subpopulations  will  be  incorporated  into  the methods  as  well.  IIEP  will  specifically 
undertake to: 
(i)  develop methods for measuring inclusive growth;  
(ii)  produce guidance and tools for applying the methods developed; and 
(iii)  produce research papers and other related research outputs.   
 
14.  The tasks set forth above will require the following: 
(i)  Principal  investigator  (international,  1.5  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
principal investigator for this project will be Professor J. Foster, who will: 
(a) provide overall intellectual leadership for the activities and serve as a focal 
point for ADB and other researchers;  and  
(b) write central components of the research and provide overall quality control for 
the research outputs; 
(ii)  Economist (international, 1.5 person-months, intermittent). The economist will: 
(a) write part of research, review other research products, and contribute to the 
compilation of research into parts of the edited volume; and 
(b) support  the  principal  investigator  in  coordinating  and  overseeing  project 
activities; 
(iii)  Assistant director (international, 3 person-months, intermittent). The assistant 
director will: 
(a) assist  in  organizing  conferences  and  workshops;  and  managing  travel, 
payments and reimbursements;  
(b) manage the economist and research assistant; and  
(c) assist the principal investigator in planning and reporting tasks; and  
(iv)  Research  assistant  (national,  3  person-months,  intermittent).  The  research 
assistant will provide technical assistance for the empirical dimensions of the 
research, including identifying datasets, carrying out econometric analyses, and 
drafting reports of results.
